statement.p: Prove that, where a, b, c, d, e are real numbers with a\neq 0, if this linear equation ax+by=c has the same solution set as this one ax+dy=e then they are the same equation. What if a=0?

answer.p: If a\neq 0 then the solution set of the first equation is this. \left\{(x,y)\text{ in }\R^2\mid x=(c-by)/a=(c/a)-(b/a)\cdot y\right\} Thus, given y we can compute the associated x. Taking y=0 gives the solution (c/a,0), and since the second equation ax+dy=e is supposed to have the same solution set, substituting into it gives that a(c/a)+d\cdot 0=e, so c=e. Taking y=1 in (*) gives a((c-b)/a)+d\cdot 1=e, and so b=d. Hence they are the same equation. When a=0 the equations can be different and still have the same solution set: e.g. 0x+3y=6 and 0x+6y=12.

statement.p: Is there a system of linear equations in two variables x, y for which solution set is all of \R^2, i.e., for which every ordered pair of real numbers (x, y) satisfies the system?

answer.p: Yes, this one-equation system: 0x+0y=0 is satisfied by every ordered pair (x, y) in \R^2.

statement.p:
Consider the matrix equation Ax = b, where A=\mat{1 3 8 0;0 1 2 1; 0 1 2 4} \text{ and } b=\vec{1 1 1}.
Write the solution set to Ax = b as a translate of a span.
What best describes the geometric relationship between the solutions to Ax = 0 and the solutions to Ax = b? (Same A and b as above.)
They are both lines through the origin.
They are parallel lines.
They are both planes through the origin.
They are parallel planes.

ol.li: The solution set to Ax = b is a line which does not go through the origin: it is a vector plus the span of a nonzero vector. Hence the solution set to Ax = 0 is the parallel line through the origin, since the solution set to Ax = b is obtained from the solution set to Ax = 0 by translating.
